discussion.content:
I guess, Its "Honeypot" , 
A honeypot is a controlled and safe environment for showing how attackers work and examining different types of threats. With a honeypot, security staff won't be distracted by real traffic using the network - they'll be able to focus 100% on the threat. Honeypots can also catch internal threats

comments.content: Honeynet is a group of honeypots.

questions.question_text: A company network is currently under attack. Although security controls are in place to stop the attack, the security administrator needs more information about the types of attacks being used. Which of the following network types would BEST help the administrator gather this information?

comments.content: Pivoting is using one machine to find hidden networks.

discussion.content:
I think this is Pivoting.
Answer: A
This is literally the definition of pivoting. Answer: A

Selected Answer: B
According to Darill Gibson the steps are:
Reconnaissance (footprinting)
Initial Explotation
Persistence
Lateral Movement
Privilege Escalation
Pivoting (Pivoting is the process of using various tools to gain additional
information.)

So pivoting comes well behind. And during persistence attacker needs to gain more control over the system, as specified at the end of the question. I'd go with B. persistence

A. Pivoting

Read it this way:

Once an initial exploit is used to gain persistent access,
For the purpose of establishing further control of a system, Moving laterally within a network is known as:

I'll go with the provided answer just because of this line "used to gain persistent access for the purpose of establishing further control of a system". The first line of the question is like telling you the attacker already pivoted and his ultimate goal is to be Persistent on the host.
`Moving laterally within a network` is the critical part of the question that we need to focus. Persistance already done next step Pivoting

• Persistence
• Once you’re there, you need to make sure there’s a way back in
• Set up a backdoor
• Build user accounts, change or verify default passwords

Persistence
§ Ability of an attacker to maintain a foothold inside the compromised 
network
From Dion's Training material
Yes Persistence is correct, now Pivoting is when a system on the network is compromised that same system will start attacking on other systems that are on the same network.

I'd have to go with A.

Having obtained a persistent foothold on the network and performed internal reconnaissance, the next likely objective is to obtain a pivot point. This is a system and/or set of privileges that allow the tester to compromise other network systems (lateral spread). The tester likely has to find some way of escalating the privileges available to him/her. For example, the initial exploit might give him/her local administrator privileges. He or she might be able to use these to obtain system privileges on another machine and then domain administrator privileges from another pivot point.

I think must be Pivoting.. All the clues (leterally, initial, further control) shows Pivoting and privileged escalation. Here is the explanation from Darril: 

After initial exploitation, a penetration tester uses privilege escalation techniques to gain more access. Pivoting during a penetration test is the process of using an exploited system to access other systems
After reading twice, before this sentence is definitely Pivoting , after it is persistence " the purpose of establishing further control of a system is known as:"

Lateral Movement - The adversary is trying to move through your environment. Lateral Movement consists of techniques that adversaries use to enter and control remote systems on a network. Following through on their primary objective often requires exploring the network to find their target and subsequently gaining access to it. Reaching their objective often involves pivoting through multiple systems and accounts to gain. Adversaries might install their own remote access tools to accomplish Lateral Movement or use legitimate credentials with native network and operating system tools, which may be stealthier.
This question has elements of all three Pivoting, Persistence and Lateral Movement - I will stick with the given answer against my better judgment

PIVOT - In penetration testing (or hacking in general), a pivot is the action or ability to compromise a system, and then use the privileges or access gained through the attack to focus attention on another target that may not have been visible or exploitable initially. It is the ability to adjust the focus or the target of an intrusion after the initial foothold is gained. 

PERSISTENCE- is the characteristic of an attack that maintains remote access to and control over a compromised target. A persistent attack grants the attacker ongoing prolonged access to and control over a victim system and/or network.

comments.content: You think the act of "gaining persistence" is defined as "persistence"?
Yes but if you read the question they’ve already gained persistence, so next up is pivoting.

discussion.content: The answer is correct . Key words " to gain persistent acces" . Do not confuse other please!!!1

comments.content: Correct. But what about the lateral movement part of the question ?

discussion.content:
I found this:

 Persistence

The adversary is trying to maintain their foothold.

Persistence consists of techniques that adversaries use to keep access to systems across restarts, changed credentials, and other interruptions that could cut off their access. Techniques used for persistence include any access, action, or configuration changes that let them maintain their foothold on systems, such as replacing or hijacking legitimate code or adding startup code.

https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003/

The given answer is correct. 
 Persistence =Ability of an attacker to maintain a foothold inside the compromised
network.

Having obtained a persistent foothold on the network and performed internal
reconnaissance, the next likely objective is to obtain a pivot point. This is a
system and/or set of privileges that allow the tester to compromise other network
systems (lateral spread).

Persistence is essentially hiding, maintaining access after gaining access.
However, before that it's pivoting, to get elevated rights.

This is a suggestive question, as many others in this test where they're throwing a term in the question just to confuse you, but it really comes down to reading&comprehension.

persistence is wen attacker maintain remote access over compromised target.
but in pivot it's the ability to compromise system and use it to get Privileged or get access to another target on the netwrok.
so the answer is B

A persistence system is one where changes are possible. Changes may be performed by authorized users, administrators, automated processes, or malware. To reduce the risk of change, various protection and recovery measures may need to be established.

I got this explanation from James M. Stewart's book Comptia Security+ Review Guide - Fourth edition, so matches with answer selected

Persistence - Escalation and Lateral Movement
Once initial access has been gained, attackers insert malware into an organization’s network to move to the second phase, expansion. They move laterally to map the network and gather credentials such as account names and passwords in order to access critical business information.

comments.content: Then what is pivoting?

questions.question_text: Moving laterally within a network once an initial exploit is used to gain persistent access for the purpose of establishing further control of a system is known as:

discussion.content: VM escape lets you break out of the VM. Answer is correct

Cloudburst virtual machine escape is an exploit method that enables a guest-level virtual machine (VM) to attack its host. ... A VM escape gives the attacker access to the host operating system and all other virtual machines running on that host.
Provided answer is correct.
VM sprawl occurs when an organization has many VMs that aren't managed properly. ... VM escape is an attack that allows an attacker to access the host system from within the virtual system

VM Escape (Virtual Machine escape): An exploit that enables a hacker to move from within a virtual machine to the hypervisor, thereby gaining access to the entire computer and all the virtual machines running within it.

source: https://www.pcmag.com/encyclopedia/term/vm-escape
Why would this not be migration?

comments.content: With respect why would it be? It’s VM escape

questions.question_text: A systems administrator is increasing the security settings on a virtual host to ensure users on one VM cannot access information from another VM. Which of the following is the administrator protecting against?

discussion.content: The answer should be D. Something you know and Something you have.

comments.content: Agreed and verified against exam bank answers for Security + 501 exam.
So sorry Just confirming you are saying it is D?
It would help if you would explain what you are saying. Is it or is it not D A B C D ?
Great. Is it D or A. Vague statements does not help anyone.

Even i fell answer should be D.
A. 802.1x is Port-Based Network Access Control. Have not heard of any implementation of 802.1x over VPN technologies i know of.
B. Redundant - Not valid answer.
C. RBAC does not make sense in this Context.
So I vote D to be the best answer.

802.1x VPN does exist, the presumption is you've already logged into your workstation.

Juniper for example has a VPN client that could be configured to work with 802.1x using a certificate to validate identity and not prompting for additional credentials as you've already "logged" into the workstation using credentials. 

The problem is a certificate is something you have, and the OTP will require something you have as well - Token, Phone, etc.
https://www.securew2.com/solutions/802-1x/
Sorry, meant to say CORRECT ANSWER is D

discussion.content:
Answer: A
802.1x is a port-based authentication and I have not seen to be mentioned as an authentication factor. If, let's say, we consider it an authentication factor, it will be something you have: your device with an authorized MAC/port + OTP (something you have based o a token) is not multifactor auth
username/pass + TOTP = something you know + something you have = 2FA

IDK if this will help anyone... but OTP is not in the Acronyms list on CompTias site.
So, yea, just throwing that out there that I think the answer is D based off the answer and the fact that OTP is not "officially" on the exam to know list.

A time-based one-time password (TOTP) is a temporary passcode generated by an algorithm that uses the current time of day as one of its authentication factors. Time-based one-time passwords are commonly used for two-factor authentication and have seen growing adoption by cloud application providers.
Answer is D 
Totp is a one time token used as something you have and password/un is something you remember

comments.content: TOTP is a security token generated via cellphone or smart phone app which is considered under something you have

discussion.content: It wont be D because they are both something you know process control so A is correct

The problem with A is these are both things you'd "have".

For 802.1x you'd require a certificate which you "have" installed on the workstation. The OTP would require a hard token, or device to receive the OTP.

D. Actually fits the requirements of MFA or in this case 2FA - Something you know, Something you have. If there was a 3rd layer it would become MFA - Something you are - Finger print, facial, etc.

Hard to argue with the network gods themselves.
"The VPN Access Control Using 802.1X Authentication feature allows enterprise employees to access their enterprise networks from home while allowing other household members to access only the Internet."

https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/ios-xml/ios/sec_usr_8021x/configuration/15-0m/sec-vpn-ac-802-1x.html

The home access router provides connectivity to the corporate network through a Virtual Private Network (VPN) tunnel through the Internet. The feature uses the IEEE 802.1X protocol framework to achieve the VPN access control

802.1x requires a username/pw (something you know)
OTP is a one-time code, which changes every time (something you have)

More support for D:
Mike Meyers SY0-501 p149 "OTPs typically are generated by tokens or mobile devices to facilitate multifactor authentication"
802.1X provide authentication to VPN and something you know. TOTP provide something you have.
I believe TOTP is something you have so D will be the answer. In a similar question TOTP was also discussed to be something you have.

comments.content: "TOTP (Time-based, One-Time Password) is a form of MFA that uses a randomly generated code as an additional authentication token. TOTP MFA codes are generally created via a smartphone app (e.g. Google Authenticator), so it falls under the “something you have” classification."
plus the question is talking about the use of VPN, from my knowledge username/password with TOTP to connect to the VPN is extremely common with companies.

discussion.content: Another vote for D. 802.1x isn't generally mentioned in multifactor. User/Pass + OTP is definitely multifactor.
802.11x refers to wireless connection and OTP refers to token that provides one-time password. I use both methods in order to connect to my job's vpn

comments.content: So sorry, I read wrong. 802.1x refers to port-based Network Access Control, so basically you require a device that needs a LAN connectivity to the internet and in order to connect to the vpn, you need a OTP device to access the company's VPN, so I still believe best answer is A
Lots of things use a password and then a one time password for authentication. A password is something you know and a time-based onetime-password/secure token is something you have.

discussion.content: As it doesn’t make sense to implement a password as well as a one time password, the network protocol that allows for authentication, as well as the authentication itself (otp) is needed. The provided answer is correct.
802.1x is RADIUS. It is also Multifactor authentication, correct? As it also needs a username and password plus the OTP. Confusing

questions.question_text:
A network administrator is implementing multifactor authentication for employees who travel and use company devices remotely by using the company VPN.
Which of the following would provide the required level of authentication?

comments.content: Key stretching and encryption are totally different dude

discussion.content: Would BCRYPT technically be a correct answer as well? BCRYPT is a key stretching but it uses blowfish (symmetric) over and over. Technically isn't this using 1 key as well?
The question is looking for Symmetric Algo's. 3DES & RC4 are the only one's.

comments.content: and it is still symmetric? The 3 means it goes through its cipher algorithm 3 times.
3DES does not need 3 keys bro. The provided answer is correct
DSA is digital sig...anytime you use a sig algo, you will encrypt with yo privates, and they can decrypt with yo public!! Provided answers are correct....for once!

Actually 3DES can use either 1, 2, or 3 different keys.

Symmetric algos: DES, 3DES, RC4, AES, Blowfish, Twofish

Block Cipher Modes: ECB, CBC, CTR, GCM

Asymmetric algos: DFE, RSA, DSA, ECC, PGP

Hashing algos: MD5, SHA1, SHA2, HMAC, RIPEMD

Key stretching libraries: BRCRYPT, PBKDF2

discussion.content: 3DES needs 3 keys. I'd go with RC4 and DSA
